title: What non-European classical music composers I should check? - Quora

response.answer_text: Australia has some very fine composers, many of whom reflect the heat and epic vastness of the landscape in their music. Some, like Peter Sculthorpe, incorporate elements of Aboriginal music such as rain sticks and the didgeridoo. The following piece doesn’t need them to evoke the primeval mood of dense mangrove forests stretching over thousands upon thousands of square kilometres in northern Australia. Mangrove  Ross Edwards is similarly influenced by First Nations culture. Often his music exhibits an almost ‘classical’ poise, gravitating towards a mixolydian modal centre instead of the traditional dominant-to-tonic relationship. In addition he’s fascinated by the clicks and chirps of the avian and insect worlds, sometimes heard in the form of tiny melodic and rhythmic motifs frequently reappearing throughout a work. This is but one characteristic of his style that has led some commentators to inaccurately label him a minimalist. Being a true original, he’s nowhere near that easy to pigeon-hole. Here’s his Violin Concerto. Maninyas  Many Australian composers are proudly multicultural. One well worth investigating, whose background is Russian, is Elena Kats-Chernin. Also a fine pianist who has made many recordings of her own works, she is a prolific polystylist composer who receives commissions from soloists, chamber groups and orchestras worldwide. Sometimes jazz-infused, her music is as urbane as Poulenc’s, Rorem’s and Piazzola’s, but with a lot more deep blues and purples. Here’s something in bright colours. Eliza’s Aria from the ballet Wild Swans.  Another composer being increasingly recognised internationally is Georges Lentz, born in Luxembourg. In addition to its Australian-ness, his music is informed by a deep engagement with astronomy and existentialism. Georges Lentz - Wikipedia It’s impossible to sum up in a few words the intense focus and almost visceral sensuality with which Lentz evokes the cosmic spirit of the Australian outback, a space that can be overwhelming, unnerving and frightening to European sensibilities unused to complex textures of emptiness. It’s best to hear the music itself. Perhaps the most edgy of his works is the hour-long Ingwe for solo electric guitar, available in a performance by Zane Banks on a Naxos recording, but not complete on YouTube. To me, it’s a concentrated paean to the alien, terrifying beauty of burning, blindingly glaring Nothing, with obligatory sharp rocks underfoot and merciless swarms of sweat-sucking flies, perhaps the best evocation of that particular characteristic of the Australian outback since the classic film Wake in Fright, though there are no people anywhere in Lentz’s vision to humanise it. Even the solo guitarist is quickly obliterated by shattering flares of electronic feedback. In the quiet second half, any sense of horizon there may have been finally disappears; the landscape merges with space itself. I love the piece when in the right euphorically bleak or bleakly euphoric mood, but it’s definitely not for everybody. I won’t link an excerpt as it deserves to be heard as the composer intended - in toto. Here’s a more ‘accessible’ work. Caeli enarrant… VII, “Mysterium”: Monh - for viola and orchestra.

lots of good American composers. I am trying to list composers who were not born in Europe - many European composers fled the Nazis and died in Hollywood or elsewhere in the US. Also I have not listed composers whose primary music was for the movies but those composers are American and very good.
